Vertical Description: OTAs, digital aggregators for hotels, activities and digital travel utilities
Vertical Intro:
Travel faces one of the highest disruption risks across all verticals, with AI collapsing the entire journey from inspiration to booking into single conversational flows. 

With minimal customer loyalty and heavy reliance on search channels that AI now owns, OTAs risk becoming invisible data suppliers. The industry's web-heavy model leaves brands without defensible owned channels as complex travel queries become single AI prompts.
Quote 1 (text): The rigid booking flow we’re used to…origin, destination, dates and filters doesn’t have to exist in an AI world.
Quote 1 (credit): Head of Marketing, Global Travel App
Quote 2 (text): Users jump between suppliers; loyalty is fragmented across flights, hotels, and cars.
Quote 2 (credit): Head of Marketing, Global Travel App
Quote 3 (text): Our first-party traveler data is what will make or break us in terms of how we monetize with AI.
Quote 3 (credit): VP Strategy & Marketing, Global Travel App
AI Disruption Risk Intro: AI/LLMs reshape planning and booking, exposing weak loyalty and fragile trust
Discovery Risk (description): High risk as AI compresses inspiration, search, and comparison into one flow
Service Disruption Risk (description): Travel highly exposed as AI/LLM intermediates data and booking flows
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Price and availability data are already aggregated by metasearch; AI can extend this and reduce reliance on existing platforms. Limited regulatory barriers on merchant transactions & licensing requirements
Customer Relationship Intro: Low customer relationship strength due to weak loyalty, higher paid traffic and greater engagement on web
Acquisition Strength (description):
Organic traffic is moderate, with SEO and direct
playing a major role alongside paid SEM
Loyalty Strength (description):
Loyalty is low to moderate; repeat behavior exists
but is fragmented across flights, hotels, and cars,
with brand trust varying by product type
Platform Engagement Depth (description):
Engagement is spread across web and app, with
metasearch engines central to comparison, supported
by social, display, and messaging apps

Vertical Description: Mobile games across casual, mid-core and social formats
Example Apps: Roblox, Candy Crush, Monopoly Go, Pokemon Go, Royal Match
Vertical Intro:
Mobile Gaming enjoys some protection from service disruption but relatively weak loyalty creates some vulnerability from discovery disruption. 

While AI cannot replicate gameplay or live operations, moderate retention and paid-heavy acquisition leave gaming exposed as discovery channels shift. App-native engagement provides defense, but without stronger retention mechanics, user acquisition costs may climb.
Quote 1 (text): AI is great for speeding up creative iterations, but it doesn't replace the actual game or the player experience—those come from years of development, IP, and live-ops.
Quote 1 (credit): Product Marketing Director, Leading Gaming Publisher
Quote 2 (text): Compared to other industries, gaming has a lower risk of AI taking over the service, because the unique value is the proprietary pool of IP, player data, and communities that only publishers control.
Quote 3 (text): If I want direct, immediate access and visuals of the games, I'll just go to the App Store. ChatGPT will only send me links there, so the app stores remain the primary anchor.
Quote 3 (credit): Product Marketing Director, Global Gaming Publisher
AI Disruption Risk Intro: High barriers in game creation and data protect against AI disruption despite moderate discovery exposure
Discovery Risk (description): Moderate disruption due to exposure to paid search and social (38% of traffic classed as at risk of AI disruption)
Service Disruption Risk (description): While AI can generate creative assets (graphics, basic design), it cannot replicate the full game development pipeline or ongoing service/community management layer
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Publishers hold proprietary gameplay and monetization data; AI cannot recreate 1P data essential to optimization
Customer Relationship Intro: Low customer relationship strength due to weak loyalty, higher paid traffic and greater engagement on web
Acquisition Strength (description):
Well-known IP, app store featuring/top lists, and social
buzz/creator clips drive a steady stream of organic
installs; paid is higher for newer IP and to support launches
Loyalty Strength (description):
Retention rides on live-ops (events promos, new
modes) and in-game personalization; engaged cohorts
remain around event cycles, while casual players
churn between updates
Platform Engagement Depth (description):
Gameplay, spending, push, and notifications are
entirely app-native; web is secondary (trailers,
support, etc.)

Vertical Description: Digital-first learning platforms, classroom support tools, and study-aid platforms
Vertical Intro: Education faces the second-highest disruption risk as LLMs can deliver personalized lessons at near-zero cost. With moderate retention and heavy SEO reliance, pure content platforms are vulnerable while those with certifications maintain some defense. The shift from "searching to learn" to "AI teaches directly" threatens traditional online education models unless platforms emphasize credentials and human validation.
Quote 1 (text): Search has historically been our strongest channel, but we're seeing growing pressure as AI summaries start showing up even above paid results.
Quote 1 (credit): Global Head of Marketing & Strategy, Education App
Quote 2 (text): In education, where information is a commodity, LLMs can deliver personalized lessons at near-zero marginal cost.
AI Disruption Risk Intro: High exposure to AI disruption driven by both discovery & service disruption from replicable workflows and less content barriers
Discovery Risk (description): High disruption due to strong exposure to organic channels and paid search (29%)
Service Disruption Risk (description):
LLMs can already create full course
flows, practice materials and quizzes;
certification is only piece they cannot
yet replicate
Data Access & Regulatory (description):
Most learning content and knowledge
domains are publicly available, with no
proprietary ownership
Customer Relationship Intro: Customer relationships moderate due to slightly lower loyalty and greater engagement on web-based platforms
Acquisition Strength (description):
Education queries drive steady stream of organic
demand ("learn Python," "best online MBA"), supported
by SEO/AEO and higher education partnerships; paid
channels used for supplemental growth
Loyalty Strength (description):
Learners in certificate or cohort-based programs tend
to persist, aided by progress nudges and structured
deadlines; casual learners drop off faster
Platform Engagement Depth (description):
Apps are central for micro-learning, quizzes, and
reminders. Long videos and assignments still skew
web-first; both app
and web play complementary roles in sustaining
engagement

Example Apps: CNN, BBC, Newsbreak, NYTimes, Reuters, Fox News
Vertical Intro: News faces the highest disruption risk with AI summarizing stories in zero-click answers. Organic traffic has already fallen 26% as LLMs aggregate and summarize content. With weak loyalty and overwhelming web dependence, publishers must pivot to investigative depth and direct reader relationships through apps and newsletters or risk becoming invisible content suppliers to AI systems.
Quote 1 (text): When someone clicks from an ad and comes to our site, they're still highly likely to subscribe. But if they've already gotten the content from the LLM, they might not need more—they're less likely to convert.
Quote 1 (credit): SVP Brand Marketing, Leading News Publisher
Quote 2 (text): Big events like elections, economic shifts, breaking news are a big component of driving intent and organic traffic; that triggers search often.
Quote 2 (credit): SVP Brand Marketing, Leading News Publisher
Quote 3 (text): Price and loyalty discounts also anchor retention, alongside brand trust and exclusive reporting.
Quote 3 (credit): SVP Brand Marketing, Leading News Publisher
AI Disruption Risk Intro: High eposure to AI disruption as LLMs summarize news and shift discovery channel mix
Discovery Risk (description): Moderate disruption due to exposure to social, paid search, and organic search
Service Disruption Risk (description):
LLMs already summarize/curate news in
zero-click answers; can deliver daily
briefs that substitute for browsing
publisher site
Data Access & Regulatory (description):
Core content (headlines, summaries, historical articles) is widely available and crawlable

Proprietary archives/user data exist,but LLMs can answer many queries from public/partnered sources

Few active regulations today; no rules prevent aggregation to answer queries
Customer Relationship Intro: Strong loyalty anchors engagement, yet paid conversion and engagement primarily on web makes customer relationship thin
Acquisition Strength (description):
Organic pull from search, direct, and social sharing; big
news cycles (elections, economic shifts, breaking news)
drive spikes. Paid mostly amplifies subscription offers
and boosts key stories
Loyalty Strength (description):
Retention built on daily habits, brand trust, and
subscription value (exclusive reporting, pricing) for
core users, but casual readers don't form strong
routines. CRM nudges (email/push, price offers) used
to sustain engagement and limit churn

Vertical Description: Digital retailers, online review platforms and leasing platforms
Example Apps: Carvana, Edmunds, CarGurus, Autotrader, Kelly's blue book
Vertical Intro: Auto marketplaces face high disruption as AI aggregates listings and connects buyers directly to sellers. With the lowest relationship strength and heavy web dependence, pure lead-gen models risk disintermediation. Only those with proprietary inventory, dealer integrations, and real-time data feeds maintain defensibility as AI reshapes car shopping from browsing to conversational queries.
Quote 1 (text): Discovery for cars is very visual - users want to see the listings, apply filters and compare. AI guidance can help, but it doesn’t replace browsing.
Quote 2 (text): Apps are mainly for core subscribers, but the classified browsing journey remains dominated by desktop and mobile web.
Quote 3 (text): We're seeing less visibility on Google due to AI Overviews, but traffic still flows through search—car buyers want specifics, not summaries.
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Rising disruption threat as AI tools aggregate listings and connect buyers and sellers, but proprietary inventory remains a moat
Discovery Risk (description): Moderate disruption due to exposure to affiliates and paid search
Service Disruption Risk (description): AI can aggregate listings, summarize options, and connect buyers and sellers; full handoff (verification, payment) still depends on marketplace infrastructure
Data Access & Regulatory (description):
Used car marketplaces hold proprietary inventory feeds and financing integrations; new card data and dealer info is broadly public

No known regulations against AI list/transacting used cars online
Customer Relationship Intro: Customer relationships limited by infrequent purchases and web-heavy engagement
Acquisition Strength (description): Large share of traffic comes organically through direct visits, search, and SEO. Paid channels drive app installs and new users, but cost is high at first touchpoint
Loyalty Strength (description): Retention limited by long vehicle purchase cycles: most users return only when actively in market, then drop off once vehicle purchase is complete
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Consumption remains web-heavy (desktop/mobile), as listings, filters, and dealer contact forms are optimized for web. App usage is limited

Vertical Description: Digital-first marketplaces, re-commerce platforms, discount/deal platforms, and omni-channel retailers' digital storefronts
Example Apps: Amazon, Temu, Shein, eBay, Etsy, Walmart
Vertical Intro: Retail faces severe disruption as agentic commerce enables AI to handle shopping end-to-end. Despite moderate loyalty, heavy exposure to search channels and AI's ability to aggregate product data threaten direct relationships. Amazon's "Buy for Me" signals a future where retailers without unique inventory or fulfillment become commoditized suppliers in an AI-mediated marketplace.
Quote 1 (text): That page is not just for people like you, it is very specifically for you and your household… 100% personalized in almost every case, sooner rather than later.
Quote 1 (credit): Head of Media, Global eCommerce Brand
Quote 2 (text): We are a business that's about 80 to 90% repeat business in a given month... but our trouble is mid-funnel, and that's why we spend a decent amount of money on the buyer side on promotions and life cycle.
Quote 3 (text): The bulk of our traffic is organic, meaning from organic social or just direct traffic that happens on its own - somewhere around 60-70%.
Quote 3 (credit): Head of Media, Global eCommerce Brand
AI Disruption Risk Intro: From discovery to checkout, AI agents displace conventional online retail touchpoints
Discovery Risk (description): Product search shifts to AI agents, weakening retailer-owned channels
Service Disruption Risk (description): AI agents can handle shopping journeys end-to-end, reducing reliance on retailer sites
Data Access & Regulatory (description): AI/LLM tools surface pricing, product, and reviews, pulling traffic away from owned platforms
Customer Relationship Intro: Retail thrives on strong acquisition strength, yet struggles with loyalty and engagement on app-platforms
Acquisition Strength (description): Organic demand is strong, with direct traffic, branded search, and word-of-mouth making up the bulk of growth. Paid media plays a supporting rather than primary role
Loyalty Strength (description): Retention is moderate to strong. Repeat purchasing is common, but customers often multi-home and chase deals, creating steady churn presure
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Apps are strong for actual transactions, but web browsing is still important for product discovery, comparisons, and checking promotions

Vertical Description: Digital-first wellness, fitness, mediation, nutrition, and workout-tracking applications
Example Apps: Myfitness pal, Strava, Calm, Peloton, Alltrails
Vertical Intro: Health & Fitness faces high disruption as LLMs can generate workout plans and wellness advice. With moderate loyalty and over 30% of traffic from disrupted channels, apps must differentiate through customization, validation and through leveraging proprietary data. Those emphasizing human expertise, device integration, and clinical accuracy can defend (as well as leverage AI/LLMs for advantage) against more generic AI generate content.
Quote 1 (text): App store discoverability is going to be at risk - people may just go straight to ChatGPT and never search the stores.
Quote 2 (text): Fitness is a textbook case for AI creation - the content is largely public... the counterweight is consumer trust with sensitive health data - established apps have the edge there.
Quote 3 (text): A lot of '101' coaching can be generated by AI - workout plans, reminders, tips - but the reason people stay is the trusted app experience, their data history, and how we handle privacy.
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Core discovery channels face LLM bypass risk - but potential for AI fueled retention moat built on trust and 1P data
Discovery Risk (description): High disruption due to exposure to organic channels and paid search
Service Disruption Risk (description): LLMs can already auto-generate workout/meal plans, adapt difficulty and answer 'coach' questions
Data Access & Regulatory (description):
Underlying knowledge (exercise, nutritional information) is public; available data (forums etc.) can substitute proprietary data for personalization

User caution over sensitive health data may slow broad AI adoption
Customer Relationship Intro: In-app behavior reinforce moderate customer strength despite low loyalty and acquistion strength due to on/off usage
Acquisition Strength (description): Category benefits from strong word-of-mouth and creator/UCG buzz; brands with trusted expertise (tracking, coaching, programs) pull steady organic demand, with paid used to accelerate new features/seasonal launches
Loyalty Strength (description): Habit loops, personalized plans, and progress visuals keep engaged cohorts active; churn is episodic (injury, life events), leading to moderate retention
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Core experience (tracking, coaching, notifications, sync) lives in-app; ongoing usage and monetization happens almost entirely in app; web plays supporting role for education/SEO content and sign-up

Vertical Description: Mobile-first dating and matchmaking apps with direct consumer interactions
Vertical Intro: Dating remains protected by network effects as AI cannot replicate real human profiles. However, moderate loyalty and episodic usage create vulnerability. With moderate traffic from disrupted channels and users increasingly asking AI for relationship advice, platforms must may look to strengthen retention through community features and adjacent networks (BFF, professional) before AI reshapes discovery.
Quote 1 (text): People still rely on word-of-mouth and friends, but Gen Z is already starting to ask ChatGPT for relationship advice - and that share will only grow.
Quote 1 (credit): Director, Product Marketing, Global Dating App
Quote 2 (text): Dating is an app-first category... web is mostly FAQs; installs and monetization are almost entirely mobile.
Quote 2 (credit): Director, Product Marketing, Global dating app
Quote 3 (text): UGC and cultural moments on TikTok/IG reduce blended CPI; great creative plus social proof is more effective than traditional upper-funnel buys.
Quote 3 (credit): Director, Product Marketing, Global dating app
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Low overall AI disruption risk; core services are protected by service and data moats, even with moderate discovery disruption
Discovery Risk (description): Moderate disruption due to paid search, organic channels and social exposure
Service Disruption Risk (description): Early use cases for LLMs providing companionship/relationship advice, but AI cannot replicate core service network of authentic userse and social interactions
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Dating apps hold proprietary, sensitive profile and behavioral data (swipes, chats) that are not publicaly available and cannot be recreated
Customer Relationship Intro: Network effects and in-app behavior reinforce moderate customer strength despite low loyalty due to on/off usage
Acquisition Strength (description): Category is culturally top-of-mind and brand-led, large share of installs come from word-of-mouth and social buzz/network effects rather than paid capture
Loyalty Strength (description): Users engage in recurring "on/off" cycles, but while active they're highly engaged due to daily swiping, messaging, and event-driven features; subscription/boosts and personalized prompts keep sessions frequent until life status changes
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Matching, messaging, push notifications, and safety features are app-native; virtually all traffic and monetization occur in-app, with web only used for FAQ/nominal purposes

Vertical Description: Consumer-facing AI/LLM assistants, chatbots, and content creation apps
Vertical Intro: Gen AI platforms face unique positioning , they are the disruptors but struggle with retention. With 40% traffic from vulnerable channels and episodic usage patterns, platforms must build stickiness through distribution partnerships and specialized use cases. Success depends on becoming indispensable infrastructure rather than novelty tools.
Quote 1 (text): Most of our growth is still organic... people see an answer link or a shared thread and try it themselves.
Quote 2 (text): We see a lot of 'multi-home' behavior the same user might ask us for research, then jump to another model for code.
Quote 3 (text): We're still leaning heavily on paid channels - affiliates and search are easiest way to scale quickly when you don't yet have default status with users. The challenge is it's fragile; if those paid channels shift, traffic is immediately impacted.
AI Disruption Risk Intro: High discovery disruption due to high exposure to affiliates and paid search
Discovery Risk (description): High disruption due to high exposure to affiliates and paid search
Customer Relationship Intro: Paid pull drives Gen AI adoption, limited by fragmented usage behavior and competition leading to moderate overall customer relationship strength
Acquisition Strength (description): Category benefits from strong word-of-mouth , social buzz, and PR around new model features; free tiers and "share this answer" links generate steady organic demand, with paid users used to amplify launches
Loyalty Strength (description): Usage is recurring but episodic - many users spread activity across multiple GenAI apps; habits form around specific jobs (summaries, drafting, research) while casual users churn faster
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Chat, voice input and notifications largely in-app; web reamins important for longer sessions and desktop workflows

Vertical Description: Digital-first sports betting, online casino apps, and skill-based real money based platforms
Example Apps: Fan Duel, DraftKings, Betfair, Bet MGM, William Hill
Vertical Intro: RMG remains insulated by regulatory barriers and real-time odds that AI cannot replicate. However, weak loyalty from multi-homing and promo-chasing creates vulnerability. With 35% traffic from disrupted channels and moderate retention, platforms must strengthen relationships through personalization and VIP programs before discovery channels shift further.
Quote 1 (text): It's an app business... almost all of [our customers] are going to be organic on any given day just based on the purchase frequency of the category... for us, brand trust is the number one factor.
Quote 2 (text): 50% of bets are live betting... the biggest barrier is the infrastructure to price markets in real time. It's illegal to place a bet for someone else, you must have a license.
Quote 3 (text): For Casino & Sports betting, disruption risk is low - operators rely on proprietary models and fast-moving odds that AI can't easily replicate.
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Casino & Sports betting (RMG) remains resilient as regulatory, data, and workflow barriers limit AI/LLM disruption
Discovery Risk (description): Moderate disruption risk driven by mixed exposure to high disruption channels, mitigated by high share of organic traffic
Service Disruption Risk (description): Live betting requires continous real-time odds refresh, which AI cannot currently replicate
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Operators rely on proprietary 1P data models to generate betting odds. Such models and feeds are tightly controlled and inaccessible to LLMs
Customer Relationship Intro: Moderate overall customer loyalty is pulled up by strong organic drivers and deep app engagement with customers
Acquisition Strength (description): Organic pull is strong, fueled by brand and direct search, plus major event-driven spikes that amplify demand
Loyalty Strength (description): Loyalty is moderate as many players multi-home and pursue short term promotions, driving churn despite strong brand presence
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Apps dominate engagement once deposits are made, though web remains important for odds shopping, registration, and checking promotions

Vertical Description: Digital productivity, communication and collaboration platforms
Vertical Intro: Productivity tools face high disruption pressure as AI agents replicate workflows, but strong loyalty from deep integration buys time. With 40% traffic from vulnerable channels (therefore high chance of discovery disruption) yet strong retention scores, platforms must embed AI capabilities directly and leverage community templates to maintain relevance as standalone AI threatens to absorb basic productivity functions.
Quote 1 (text): The goal is to make the experience as sticky as possible so people stay in their accounts and keep engaging.
Quote 1 (credit): Head of Growth Marketing, Global productivity platform
Quote 2 (text): There are companies that have had big drops in traffic, but the traffic was lower quality to begin with... some are now seeing fewer, but much higher intent visitors coming from ChatGPT.
Quote 2 (credit): Head of Growth Marketing, Global productivity platform
Quote 3 (text): I haven't seen a lot of successes where workflows are fully transformed into a chat interface. AI works best as a companion to existing interfaces, not a replacement.
Quote 3 (credit): Head of Growth Marketing, Global productivity platform
AI Disruption Risk Intro: High risk of both discovery and service disruption, driven by AI integration pressure on workflow offerings
Discovery Risk (description): High disruption as organic and paid search are heavily exposed to AI overviews (41% of traffic classed as highly likely to be disrupted)
Service Disruption Risk (description): Core features are sticky today, but AI agents are rapdily learnign to replicate workflows
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Security reviews and integration hurdles slow adoption, but these are procedural, not structural barriers. As of today no regulatory shield to prevent AI disruption
Customer Relationship Intro: Deep integration in daily workflows drives loyalty with strong organic acquistion strength
Acquisition Strength (description): Organic acquistion is very strong, driven by network effects, referrals, and community driven sharing
Loyalty Strength (description): Retention is strong, driven by deep integration into users' daily workflows. Once embedded, tools become stick and are used consistently
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Engagement is very strong across web and desktop, with apps deeply embedded into workflows and daily use

Vertical Description: Digitial-first social networking, messaging, and content-sharing platforms
Example Apps: Facebook, Whatsapp, Instagram, TikTok, Telegram, Snap, Pinterest, X, Reddit
Vertical Intro: Social demonstrates maximum resilience with the strongest relationships across all verticals. Network effects and social graphs create barriers AI cannot breach, as they for the most part cannot replicate authentic human connections. With habitual usage and app dominance, social platforms can leverage AI for enhancement while maintaining their role as essential digital infrastructure.
Quote 1 (text): Discovery is moving from big platforms to niche communities where CPMs are cheaper and engagement is higher
Quote 1 (credit): Retention Lead, Global Social Media App
Quote 2 (text): People want to be where others are already engaged. It's about finding those with the ability to spend and making them succesful on the platform.
Quote 2 (credit): Retention Lead, Global Social Media App
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Discovery remains resilient with high direct share and platform loyalty, networks remain strong barriers
Discovery Risk (description): Social discovery with limited exposure to channels that AI can aggregate
Service Disruption Risk (description): The soecial graph and network effects are unique to platforms and cannot be reproduced by AI
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Proprietary engagement and relationship data stay within platforms, limiting AI's ability to replicate the service
Customer Relationship Intro: Organic acquisition strength and high loyalty due to network effects and habitual engagement drive strong customer relationships
Acquisition Strength (description): Organic discovery is extremely strong, fueled by network effects, community behaviors, and embedded usage across platform
Loyalty Strength (description): Retention is very high, anchored by daily usage platforms, habitual engagement, and network lock-in
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Engagement is overwhelmingly app-led, with mobile as the dominant access point and smaller communities adding depth

Vertical Description: Digital wallets, challenger banks, peer-to-peeer payment platforms, trading and investing apps
Example Apps: PayPal, Revolut, CashApp, Venmo, Credit Karma, Robinhood, Coinbase
Vertical Intro: FinTech maintains strong defensive position with proprietary data moats and regulatory shields. While AI can educate and compare, it cannot access bureau data or approve loans. With 71% retention and 81% app engagement, platforms like Credit Karma leverage unique approval data while selectively partnering with AI ecosystems to maintain visibility without losing control.
Quote 1 (text): AI isn't sending you ten options anymore. It's sending you one - and we need to be that one
Quote 1 (credit): Director of Growth Market, Financial Services Comparison Platform
Quote 2 (text): An LLM can tell you the 10 best balance transfer cards, but it can't tell you how likely you are to be approved. We can.
Quote 2 (credit): Director of Growth Market, Financial Services Comparison Platform
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Discovery disrupted as queries move to AI/LLMs, but proprietary data and regulatory barriers remain a moat
Discovery Risk (description): Moderate risk as search shifts to AI/LLM platforms and winner-takes-all answers
Service Disruption Risk (description): AI can rank and list products, as well as provide educational financial information shared by man companies currently
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Proprietary bureau and lender data sit with major platforms not AI/LLM - limiting replication
Customer Relationship Intro: Strong acquisition strength and sustained loyalty reflect strong customer relationship
Acquisition Strength (description): Organic traffic is very strong, with most users arriving via SEO, credit score/report services, and brand familiarity. Paid traffic plays a smaller role vs. other verticals
Loyalty Strength (description): Retention is strong, anchored by recurring use of credit scores, reports, and notifications that keep members engaged and returning regularly
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Engagement is highly app-led, with many integrated into everyday financial management

Vertical Description: Banking and consumer platforms supporting account management and personal finance
Example Apps: Chase, Wells Fargo, Citi, HSBC, BBVA, Lloyds, Capital One
Vertical Intro: Financial services enjoy maximum protection through regulatory moats and switching costs. With <30% vulnerable discovery traffic and strong retention, traditional banks face minimal AI threat. Core workflows require licenses and compliance AI cannot replicate. The opportunity lies in using AI to enhance personalization while maintaining trust and regulatory advantages that new entrants cannot match.
Quote 1 (text): Financial services will be behind other industries in agentic commerce - people still need to read terms, review details, and apply manually.
Quote 1 (credit): Head of Digital Marketing Platforms, Leading Bank
Quote 2 (text): Once customers set up direct deposit or bill pay, they're very unlikely to switch– retention is built into the way people use our products.
Quote 2 (credit): Global Head of Digital Marketing Platforms, Leading Bank
Quote 3 (text): The majority of our acquisition spend is still on digital display and paid search, with TV and social making up a much smaller share.
Quote 3 (credit): Global Head of Digital Marketing Platforms, Leading Bank
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Stable against AI disruption, supported by regulatory, data moats and low discovery disruption risk
Discovery Risk (description): Low disruption due to low exposure to organic channels
Service Disruption Risk (description):
AI can offer financial advice and
transactional tools (wallets), but cannot
replicate core products (mortgages,
accounts, etc.) that involve regulated
workflows and human verification
Data Access & Regulatory (description):
Banks' proprietary datasets of
transaction history across millions of
users are high moat for personalization
and product recommendations
Customer Relationship Intro:
Customer relationships reinforced by trust but engagement
primarily on web
Acquisition Strength (description):
Life-stage triggers (e.g., buying a home, starting
university) drive high-intent organic demand; large
banks' trust and domain authority keep them
prominent in organic results
Loyalty Strength (description):
Switching costs (direct deposit, bill pay, credit
history) keep churn low; points/rewards reinforce
retention quickly
Platform Engagement Depth (description):
Apps increasingly used for ongoing engagement (daily
banking, account management), but web still central;
web also plays secondary role for research and sign-
ups

Vertical Description: OTT video and audio platforms, digital live-streaming services
Example Apps: YouTube, Spotify, Netflix, Amazon Prime, Disney, Max, Soundcloud, Apple Music, JioHotstar, Gaana
Vertical Intro: Media & Streaming platforms benefit from content rights and licensing barriers AI cannot breach. With 76% retention and strong subscription models, they face limited disruption. While AI can recommend, it cannot access proprietary content libraries. The opportunity is using AI to enhance personalization and discovery while maintaining exclusive content as the ultimate moat.
Quote 1 (text): Gen Z are moving to TikTok for search... highly visual, influencer-driven content. Reading is no longer the default... you're watching someone demonstrate an answer and using that as your truth.
Quote 1 (credit): Head of Marketing, Global Streaming App
Quote 2 (text): The traditional entry points of SEO and app stores are expoed - AI can sit on top and redirect that traffic.
Quote 2 (credit): Head of Marketing, Global Streaming App
Quote 3 (text): Retention is built on content access and rights, not just marketing spend.
Quote 3 (credit): Head of Marketing, Global Streaming App
AI Disruption Risk Intro: AI disrupts discovery but faces rights and licensing barriers
Discovery Risk (description): High exposure as AI intermediates search, recommendations and engagement
Service Disruption Risk (description): AI can replicate recommendations and search, but licensing and production remain protected
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Strict copyright and licensing regimes prevent AI from replication, training on, or distributing protected media content, keeping disruption risk low
Customer Relationship Intro: Strong loyalty supported by recurring engagment and higher app-led engagement leading to strong customer relationship
Acquisition Strength (description): Organic demand is strong for initial installs, but performance marketing is essential to drive paid conversions and sustain growth
Loyalty Strength (description): Loyalty is strong, supported by subscription models and recurring engagement features that encourage long-term use
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Engagement spans multiple platforms, with mobile apps at the core, complemented by web and TV apps, ensuring access across devices

Vertical Description: Digital-first consumer apps for ride-hailing, food delivery, grocery delivery and QSRs
Example Apps: Uber, Doordash, Lyft, Resy, Instacart, McDonalds, Starbucks, TaskRabbit
Vertical Intro: On-demand services remain protected by real-world logistics AI cannot replicate. Relatively strong retention and proprietary merchant/courier networks, platforms face limited disruption. While AI may handle ordering, fulfillment requires physical infrastructure. The opportunity is preparing for agentic reorders while strengthening in-app discovery and cross-category expansion.
Quote 1 (text): Most of conversion today comes from promotions - but you can't offer a promo inside an LLM answer. Over time, conversion will depend more on brand trust, and eventually agentic commerce will take hold
Quote 1 (credit): Head of Marketing Strategy, Global Food Delivery App
Quote 2 (text): AI can help people decide what to order, but they can't pick up the food... even if assistant places the order, it still runs on our network and data-merchant integrations, logistics, fraud, customer care.
Quote 2 (credit): Head of Marketing Strategy, Global Food Delivery App
Quote 3 (text): Compared with digital-only categories, on-demand has lower takeover risk from AI because the value sits in proprietary merchant/courier networks and transaction data
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Logistics and proprietary, real time data protect service, while dependence on social and search creates moderate discovery disruption
Discovery Risk (description): Moderate disruption due to exposure to social, paid search, and organic search
Service Disruption Risk (description): End-to-end service lies on real-world logistics and merchant networks; LLMs can aid decisions but can't complete deliveries
Data Access & Regulatory (description): On-demand platforms hold proprietary transaction and logistics data; LLMs lack access to replicate these datasets
Customer Relationship Intro: Customers ties anchored in convenience and app-first use, despite lower loyalty
Acquisition Strength (description): Immediate, high-intent needs plus strong brand awareness and dense local coverage drive a large share of organic installs; word-of-mouth and partnerships (restaurants, retailers) reinforce pull
Loyalty Strength (description): Habit and convenience anchor repeat use; subscriptions, personalized promos, and saved favorites keep cohorts active; however, deal-seeking behavior creates some churn pressure
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Ordering, live tracking, support, substitutions, and tipping are all app-native; web has essential functionality and FAQ, but ongoing engagement and monetization are in-app

Vertical Description: Digital selling Car and 2W OEMs which have significant digital presence
Example Apps: Tesla, Rivian, Polestar, Mercedes Benz, BMW, Mazda, OLA Electric
Vertical Intro: Auto OEMs maintain strong position through brand equity and dealer networks. With 60% retention and minimal AI disruption risk, luxury brands especially remain resilient. While AI can assist configuration, high-value purchases require in-person validation. The opportunity is enhancing digital tools while preserving the aspirational brand experience that AI cannot commoditize.
Quote 1 (text): Discovery is already moving in-app - TikTok and Autotrader are embedding pricing, trade-ins and financing directly inside the platform.
Quote 2 (text): AI can replicate things like configurators or trade-in calculators, but those are already digital - the bigger question is whether people will trust it for a $50,000 purchase.
AI Disruption Risk Intro: Discovery and service face moderate disruption as AI reshapes journeys
Discovery Risk (description): Product search shifts to AI/LLM agents, weakening retailer-owned channels
Service Disruption Risk (description): Dealer tools like configurators and trade-ins are already digitized; AI adds little disruption. Strong need for in-person experience in the industry
Data Access & Regulatory (description): Fragmented data across OEMs, dealers and third parties limit AI reach
Customer Relationship Intro: Organic pull and retention are strong, yet dependence on web based engagement remains high
Acquisition Strength (description): Organic demand is strong, supported by brand equity, direct traffic, and word-of-mouth. A significant share of customers arrive without heavy reliance on paid
Loyalty Strength (description): Retention is healthy, anchored by leasing and financing cycles that create natural repeat behavior. Brand trust and aspiration further reinforce loyalty
Platform Engagement Depth (description): Automotive engagement remains centered on OEM sites, configurators, and dealer interactions. App-based traffic is limited, with digital touchpoints still largely web-driven
